pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:1.11: Jānāhi, lit. “You know.” The implied meaning is not clear. However, in commenting on a different passage, one of the sub-commentaries, Sp-ṭ.3.330, defines the word as follows: Jānāhīti cettha paṭipajjāti attho veditabbo, “And here the meaning of ‘you know’ is to be understood as ‘you undertake’.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2:2.1.30: The Pali text just says dukkaṭa, without specifying that it is an āpatti, “an offense”. Yet elsewhere, such as in bhikkhu-saṅghādisesa 10, Bu Ss 10:2.65, the dukkaṭa is annulled if you commit the full offense of saṅghādisesa. The implication is that in these contexts dukkaṭa should be read as āpatti dukkaṭassa, “an offense of wrong conduct”.
